title: Ezekiel Chapter 34 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Ezekiel chapter 34 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Ezekiel Chapter 34 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Ezekiel Chapter 34.

questions.question: Who does the LORD command Ezekiel to prophesy against in Ezekiel 34:2?
questions.correctAnswer: The shepherds of Israel
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 34:2 states that the word of the LORD came to Ezekiel saying to prophesy against the shepherds of Israel.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 34:3, what do the shepherds do instead of feeding the flock?
options: Eat the fat and clothe themselves with the wool
questions.correctAnswer: Eat the fat and clothe themselves with the wool
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 34:3 explains that the shepherds eat the fat, clothe themselves with the wool, and kill those that are fed instead of feeding the flock.

questions.question: What have the shepherds failed to do according to Ezekiel 34:4?
options: Strengthen the diseased, heal the sick, bind up the broken, bring back the driven away, and seek the lost
Build strong fences around the sheep
Move the flock to new pastures
questions.correctAnswer: Strengthen the diseased, heal the sick, bind up the broken, bring back the driven away, and seek the lost
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 34:4 says the shepherds did not strengthen the diseased, heal the sick, bind up the broken, bring back the driven away, or seek the lost.

questions.question: Why were the sheep scattered according to Ezekiel 34:5?
questions.correctAnswer: Because there was no shepherd
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 34:5 states that the sheep were scattered because there was no shepherd to tend them.

questions.question: Where did the sheep wander according to Ezekiel 34:6?
options: Through all the mountains and upon every high hill
questions.correctAnswer: Through all the mountains and upon every high hill
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 34:6 describes how the sheep wandered through all the mountains and upon every high hill.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 34:8 says the shepherds fed the flock properly.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 34:8 says the shepherds fed themselves and not the flock, so it is false that they fed the flock properly.

questions.question: What will God do to the shepherds according to Ezekiel 34:10?
options: Cause them to cease feeding the flock and stop feeding themselves
questions.correctAnswer: Cause them to cease feeding the flock and stop feeding themselves
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 34:10 says God will require His flock from the shepherds and cause them to cease feeding the flock and themselves.

questions.question: Who will God set as shepherd over His flock according to Ezekiel 34:23?
questions.correctAnswer: David
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 34:23 states God will set up one shepherd over the flock, His servant David.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 34:28 promises that the flock will no longer be prey to heathen or beasts.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 34:28 says the flock shall no more be prey to the heathen nor devoured by beasts, and they shall dwell safely.

questions.question: What will God do to the places around His hill according to Ezekiel 34:26?
options: Make them a blessing and cause showers of blessing to come
questions.correctAnswer: Make them a blessing and cause showers of blessing to come
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 34:26 states God will make the places around His hill a blessing and cause showers of blessing to fall in their season.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 34:16, what will God do to the fat and strong sheep?
options: Destroy them and feed them with judgment
Make them leaders of the flock
questions.correctAnswer: Destroy them and feed them with judgment
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 34:16 says God will destroy the fat and strong and feed them with judgment.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'I will seek that which was _______, and bring again that which was driven away.'
questions.correctAnswer: lost
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 34:16 says God will seek that which was lost and bring back that which was driven away.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 34:15, what will God cause His flock to do?
questions.correctAnswer: Lie down
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 34:15 states that God will feed His flock and cause them to lie down.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 34:31 states that the flock are men and God is their God.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 34:31 declares that the flock of God's pasture are men and that He is their God.

questions.question: What will the tree of the field do according to Ezekiel 34:27?
questions.correctAnswer: Yield fruit
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 34:27 says the tree of the field shall yield her fruit.

medium.title: Ezekiel Chapter 34 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Ezekiel Chapter 34 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with discouragement due to feeling overlooked and abandoned. Based on Ezekiel 34, what biblical truth would you share about God's care?
options: God personally seeks out and rescues those who are lost and scattered.
God allows the strong to dominate the weak without intervention.
God only cares for the righteous and ignores the weak.
God expects believers to solve all their problems independently.
questions.correctAnswer: God personally seeks out and rescues those who are lost and scattered.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 34:11-12 explains that God, like a shepherd, will search and seek out His sheep scattered in dark and cloudy places, showing His personal care for those who feel lost or abandoned.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 34 teach us about the importance of integrity and honesty in leadership within the church or family?
options: Leaders must feed themselves rather than the flock.
Leaders must rule with force and cruelty to maintain order.
Leaders must care for the weak, heal the sick, and seek the lost.
Leaders should ignore the needs of those they serve.
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders must care for the weak, heal the sick, and seek the lost.
questions.explanation: Verses 3-4 and 16 emphasize that true shepherds strengthen the sick, bind the broken, seek the lost, and feed their flock rather than themselves, highlighting the need for honest and compassionate leadership.

questions.question: A believer is experiencing conflict in their family and desires peace. According to Ezekiel 34, what hope can you share about God's provision for peace?
options: God will make a covenant of peace and cause harmful influences to cease.
God will allow conflicts to continue without resolution.
Peace comes only when others change first.
God is indifferent to family conflicts.
questions.correctAnswer: God will make a covenant of peace and cause harmful influences to cease.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 34:25 promises a covenant of peace and the removal of evil beasts, symbolizing the end of harmful forces, which can be applied to God’s promise of peace in troubled relationships.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 34 instruct believers on humility and contentment in regard to resources and blessings?
options: It condemns trampling and fouling of the pasture and water, implying respect for shared blessings.
It encourages taking as much as possible for oneself.
It teaches that wealth is a sign of God's favor to be flaunted.
It says to ignore the needs of others when prospering.
questions.correctAnswer: It condemns trampling and fouling of the pasture and water, implying respect for shared blessings.
questions.explanation: Verses 18-19 highlight the wrongdoing of trampling and fouling the pasture and water, teaching believers to be humble and content by respecting what God provides and not wasting or defiling resources.

questions.question: True or False: According to Ezekiel 34, God promises to raise up a shepherd like David to feed and care for His people.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 34:23 states God will set up one shepherd, His servant David, to feed and care for the people, symbolizing Christ’s role as the Good Shepherd.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 34 teach about perseverance through trials in the life of a believer?
options: God strengthens the sick and binds up the broken while judging the strong who oppress.
God abandons those who suffer trials.
Trials are punishment without hope for healing.
Believers must endure trials alone without God's help.
questions.correctAnswer: God strengthens the sick and binds up the broken while judging the strong who oppress.
questions.explanation: Verse 16 explains God’s active role in strengthening the sick and binding up the broken, offering hope and perseverance through trials, while His judgment ensures justice.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with forgiveness and reconciliation in their church. Based on Ezekiel 34, what biblical principle would you encourage them to practice?
options: Leaders should feed themselves and neglect the flock.
God calls leaders to feed, care for, and restore the lost and broken.
It is acceptable to rule with cruelty to maintain authority.
Conflict should be ignored rather than addressed.
questions.correctAnswer: God calls leaders to feed, care for, and restore the lost and broken.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 34:4 and 16 reveal God’s desire for shepherds to heal, bind, and restore, teaching believers the importance of care, forgiveness, and reconciliation within community.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 34 teach about generosity and stewardship in everyday life?
options: Shepherds feeding themselves rather than the flock is condemned, implying selfless care for others is required.
It encourages hoarding resources for oneself.
It promotes using resources without regard to others.
It teaches that generosity is optional.
questions.correctAnswer: Shepherds feeding themselves rather than the flock is condemned, implying selfless care for others is required.
questions.explanation: Verses 2, 8, and 10 rebuke shepherds who feed themselves instead of the flock, teaching believers to practice generosity and stewardship by caring for others’ needs first.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 34 says that God will allow the flock to remain prey to wild animals because the shepherds failed in their duties.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 34:10-12 states that God will deliver His flock from predation by wild beasts and will personally seek and save them, despite the failures of the shepherds.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 34 encourage believers to trust God in the midst of family and community struggles?
options: God promises to gather scattered people and feed them in good pastures.
God promises to leave people scattered without hope.
God expects believers to solve all problems without His help.
God ignores the struggles of His people.
questions.correctAnswer: God promises to gather scattered people and feed them in good pastures.
questions.explanation: Verses 12-14 assure that God will gather His flock from all places and feed them in good pastures, encouraging trust in His restoration and provision amid struggles.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Ezekiel 34 teaches that God will __________ that which was lost and bring again that which was driven away.
questions.correctAnswer: seek
questions.explanation: Verse 16 clearly states God will seek that which was lost and bring again that which was driven away, showing His active care for the vulnerable.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 34, what should be the attitude of a believer regarding their role in serving others in the church or family?
options: Serve selflessly, caring for the weak and seeking the lost as a shepherd would.
Serve only when it benefits oneself.
Avoid helping others to maintain personal comfort.
Rule others with force to maintain respect.
questions.correctAnswer: Serve selflessly, caring for the weak and seeking the lost as a shepherd would.
questions.explanation: Verses 3-4 and 15 emphasize the shepherd’s role to feed, heal, and care for the flock, modeling how believers should serve others selflessly.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 34 teach about the importance of prayer and trusting God during seasons of difficulty?
options: God promises showers of blessing and restoration after hardship.
God does not intervene in difficult times.
Prayer is unnecessary because God is distant.
Believers must depend solely on their own strength.
questions.correctAnswer: God promises showers of blessing and restoration after hardship.
questions.explanation: Verse 26 speaks of showers of blessing in His season, symbolizing God’s provision and blessing in due time, encouraging trust and prayer during trials.

questions.question: When believers face temptation and oppression, what hope does Ezekiel 34 offer about God's justice?
options: God will judge between the strong and the weak and save His flock.
God ignores injustice and allows the strong to prevail.
Believers should accept oppression as permanent.
Justice is only for the powerful.
questions.correctAnswer: God will judge between the strong and the weak and save His flock.
questions.explanation: Verses 17-22 describe God’s judgment between cattle (the strong and weak) and His promise to save His flock from being prey, giving hope amid oppression.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 34 encourage believers to live with gratitude and contentment in their daily lives?
options: By respecting the blessings God provides and not defiling or wasting them.
By constantly demanding more from others.
By focusing on what others have instead of what God gives.
By neglecting the needs of the community.
questions.correctAnswer: By respecting the blessings God provides and not defiling or wasting them.
questions.explanation: Verses 18-19 rebuke trampling and fouling the pasture and water, teaching believers to be grateful stewards of God’s provision and live contentedly.

hard.title: Ezekiel Chapter 34 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Ezekiel Chapter 34.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 34, who is criticized for feeding themselves instead of the flock?
questions.correctAnswer: The shepherds of Israel
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 34:2-3 explicitly condemns the shepherds of Israel for feeding themselves rather than feeding the flock.

questions.question: What metaphorical role do the leaders of Israel hold in Ezekiel 34?
questions.correctAnswer: Shepherds
questions.explanation: The leaders of Israel are depicted as shepherds responsible for caring for the flock, symbolizing the people of Israel (Ezekiel 34:2).

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 34, what consequences befell the flock due to the absence of good shepherds?
options: They were scattered and became prey to beasts
They were taken captive by foreign nations
questions.correctAnswer: They were scattered and became prey to beasts
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 34:5 describes how the sheep were scattered and became meat for beasts because there was no shepherd.

questions.question: What does God declare He will do for His flock in Ezekiel 34:11-12?
options: Search and seek them out like a shepherd
Gather them to build a temple
questions.correctAnswer: Search and seek them out like a shepherd
questions.explanation: God promises to personally search and seek His sheep as a shepherd does for scattered sheep (Ezekiel 34:11-12).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: In Ezekiel 34:23, God promises to set up one shepherd over the flock, who is identified as _______.
questions.correctAnswer: My servant David
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 34:23 foretells the establishment of one shepherd, identified as 'my servant David,' symbolizing a Messianic figure.

questions.question: What covenant does God promise to make with His people according to Ezekiel 34:25?
questions.correctAnswer: A covenant of peace
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 34:25 states God will make a covenant of peace with His people, ensuring their safety and blessing.

questions.question: In the context of Ezekiel 34, what does the imagery of 'fat cattle' and 'lean cattle' symbolize?
options: The strong and the weak among the people
The wealthy and the poor nations
The righteous and the wicked prophets
questions.correctAnswer: The strong and the weak among the people
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 34:17 and 34:20 use the imagery of fat and lean cattle to symbolize the disparity between strong and weak members of the flock, emphasizing God's judgment.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 34 portrays God as a shepherd who only judges the flock but does not tend to their needs.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: God is depicted as both judge and shepherd who seeks, heals, and strengthens His flock (Ezekiel 34:16).

questions.question: Which theme prominent in Ezekiel 34 is also central in the New Testament's depiction of Jesus?
options: The Good Shepherd who seeks and saves the lost
questions.correctAnswer: The Good Shepherd who seeks and saves the lost
questions.explanation: The shepherd motif in Ezekiel 34 foreshadows the New Testament portrayal of Jesus as the Good Shepherd (John 10), who seeks and saves lost sheep.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 34:26-27 use agricultural imagery to convey God's blessing?
options: Showers of blessing and fruitful trees
questions.correctAnswer: Showers of blessing and fruitful trees
questions.explanation: Verses 26-27 describe showers of blessing and fruitful fields as metaphors for God's provision and restoration.

questions.question: What cultural practice regarding shepherding in the ancient Near East is reflected in God's criticism of the shepherds in Ezekiel 34?
options: Shepherds were expected to protect, nourish, and seek lost sheep
Shepherds did not interact with sheep directly
questions.correctAnswer: Shepherds were expected to protect, nourish, and seek lost sheep
questions.explanation: Ancient Near Eastern shepherds were responsible for the care and protection of their flocks, a role the leaders failed at according to Ezekiel 34:4.

questions.question: What is the significance of 'David' as the shepherd set over the flock in Ezekiel 34:23-24 in the context of Israel's history?
options: David represents the ideal king and Messianic hope
David was a prophet during Ezekiel's time
David was a priest who led sacrifices
David was a foreign ruler of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: David represents the ideal king and Messianic hope
questions.explanation: David symbolizes the ideal shepherd-king and points to the future Messianic leader who will care for Israel perfectly (Ezekiel 34:23-24).

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 34:16 exhibit Hebrew parallelism in describing God's care for the flock?
options: By pairing actions like seeking the lost and binding the broken
By repeating the same word twice
questions.correctAnswer: By pairing actions like seeking the lost and binding the broken
questions.explanation: Verse 16 uses synonymous parallelism, pairing related actions to emphasize God's comprehensive care.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 34 asserts that the flock will continue to be prey for the beasts of the field due to the shepherds' neglect.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: God promises to save His flock from becoming prey and to judge the negligent shepherds (Ezekiel 34:22, 28).

questions.question: What literary device is prominently used in Ezekiel 34 to contrast the corrupt shepherds and the ideal shepherd?
questions.correctAnswer: Chiasm
questions.explanation: The chapter uses chiasm to contrast the self-serving shepherds (feeding themselves) with the ideal shepherd (God and David) who feeds the flock (Ezekiel 34:2, 23).

theological.title: Ezekiel Chapter 34 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Ezekiel Chapter 34 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 34, what is the primary responsibility of the shepherds of Israel?
options: To feed and care for the flock
To scatter the sheep among the mountains
To judge between cattle and cattle
questions.correctAnswer: To feed and care for the flock
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 34:2-4 rebukes the shepherds for feeding themselves and neglecting the flock, stating that they should strengthen the diseased, heal the sick, bind up the broken, and seek the lost. This responsibility aligns with Jesus' teaching in John 21:16 where He commands Peter to tend His sheep, and with 1 Peter 5:2 which instructs elders to shepherd the flock of God.

questions.question: What consequence does Ezekiel say will come upon the shepherds who feed themselves and neglect the flock?
options: God will require His flock at their hand and cause them to cease feeding the flock
They will be rewarded for their work
They will be given more sheep to tend
They will become leaders among Israel
questions.correctAnswer: God will require His flock at their hand and cause them to cease feeding the flock
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 34:10 declares that God will hold the shepherds accountable and stop them from feeding themselves at the expense of the flock. This judgment theme is consistent with Ezekiel 3:18, and the principle of accountability is also seen in Hebrews 13:17 and James 3:1.

questions.question: How does God describe His own role in relation to His scattered sheep in Ezekiel 34?
options: He will seek and search for His sheep and deliver them
He will abandon them to the beasts of the field
He will appoint more shepherds to care for them
He will scatter them further among the nations
questions.correctAnswer: He will seek and search for His sheep and deliver them
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 34:11-12 emphasizes God's personal commitment to seek out and rescue His scattered sheep, portraying Him as the Good Shepherd. This is echoed in Psalm 23:1-3, John 10:11 where Jesus calls Himself the Good Shepherd, and Luke 15:4-7 where the shepherd seeks the lost sheep.

questions.question: What future role does God promise to establish over His flock in Ezekiel 34?
options: One shepherd, His servant David, to feed them
Many shepherds to divide the flock
No shepherds, but they will feed themselves
The people will become their own shepherds
questions.correctAnswer: One shepherd, His servant David, to feed them
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 34:23-24 promises the establishment of a single shepherd, identified as 'my servant David,' who will feed and shepherd the people. This messianic promise points to Christ, the Son of David (Matthew 22:42-45), who is the ultimate Shepherd (Hebrews 13:20) and King (Revelation 22:16).

questions.question: What kind of covenant does God say He will make with His flock in Ezekiel 34?
questions.correctAnswer: A covenant of peace
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 34:25 states God will make a covenant of peace, causing evil beasts to cease, and providing safety. This peace covenant recalls Isaiah 54:10 and the New Testament fulfillment in Christ's peace (Ephesians 2:14-18) through the new covenant (Hebrews 8:10).

questions.question: In Ezekiel 34, how does God describe His judgment among the cattle, symbolizing His people?
options: He will judge between the fat cattle and the lean cattle
He will let all cattle graze equally
He will separate the cattle by color
He will abandon the weak cattle
questions.correctAnswer: He will judge between the fat cattle and the lean cattle
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 34:17-20 depicts God judging between strong and weak cattle, symbolizing His righteous judgment among His people. This reflects God's impartial justice (Psalm 75:7, Romans 2:11) and His care to protect the vulnerable (Psalm 68:5).

questions.question: What does God say He will do to the 'fat and the strong' among the sheep according to Ezekiel 34?
options: Allow them to lead the flock
questions.correctAnswer: Destroy them with judgment
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 34:16 says God will destroy the fat and the strong and feed them with judgment, indicating condemnation for those who exploit others. This is consistent with prophetic warnings (Isaiah 10:1-2, Jeremiah 23:1-2) and Jesus' teaching on judgment (Matthew 25:31-46).

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 34 reveal about the identity of God's flock?
options: They are men, the flock of His pasture
questions.correctAnswer: They are men, the flock of His pasture
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 34:31 clearly states that the flock is composed of men, emphasizing God's personal relationship with His people. This anthropological truth aligns with Psalm 100:3 and 1 Peter 2:9, underscoring believers as God's chosen people.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 34 describe the condition of the sheep before God intervenes?
options: Scattered, weak, sick, and prey to beasts
questions.correctAnswer: Scattered, weak, sick, and prey to beasts
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 34:4-6 describes the sheep as scattered, sick, broken, and vulnerable due to neglect by the shepherds. This imagery parallels Psalm 23:1-4 and John 10:12, highlighting the need for divine rescue and care.

questions.question: What blessings does God promise to bring upon the land and His people in Ezekiel 34?
options: Showers of blessing, fruitful trees, and safe dwelling
questions.correctAnswer: Showers of blessing, fruitful trees, and safe dwelling
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 34:26-28 promises blessings like seasonal showers, abundant fruit, and safety. This echoes God's covenantal blessings in Deuteronomy 28:12-13 and the eschatological hope in Joel 2:23 and Revelation 22:1-2.

questions.question: What does God say He will break to free His flock in Ezekiel 34?
questions.correctAnswer: The bands of their yoke
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 34:27 mentions God breaking the bands of their yoke, symbolizing liberation from oppression. This is consistent with Isaiah 58:6 and Luke 4:18 where God frees the oppressed and proclaims liberty.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 34, what is the significance of 'my servant David' as the shepherd over the flock?
options: He represents the Messianic King who will shepherd Israel
He is a literal shepherd from Ezekiel's time
He is a foreign king appointed by God
questions.correctAnswer: He represents the Messianic King who will shepherd Israel
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 34:23-24 identifies 'my servant David' as the shepherd, symbolizing the promised Messiah from David's line (2 Samuel 7:12-16). This messianic theme is affirmed in Acts 13:22-23 and Revelation 5:5 where Jesus is the Lion of Judah and descendant of David.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 34 say about God’s attitude toward those who feed themselves instead of the flock?
options: God is against them and will hold them accountable
God blesses them for their leadership
questions.correctAnswer: God is against them and will hold them accountable
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 34:8-10 clearly states God's opposition to the selfish shepherds and His intention to require the flock from their hand, showing divine justice. This aligns with Psalm 94:16 and Romans 14:12 about God's judgment on leaders.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 34 illustrate the condition of God's flock regarding the pasture and water?
options: They eat and drink what has been trampled and fouled by others
They have abundant clean pastures and water
They refuse to eat or drink
questions.correctAnswer: They eat and drink what has been trampled and fouled by others
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 34:18-19 describes how the good pasture and deep waters are trampled and fouled by some, forcing the flock to consume the spoiled remains. This metaphor highlights exploitation, consistent with Isaiah 5:6 and Jeremiah 12:10.

questions.question: What eschatological hope is expressed in Ezekiel 34 regarding the safety and provision for God's people?
options: They shall dwell safely, no longer prey to heathen or beasts
They will be scattered among the nations indefinitely
They will be hungry and ashamed
questions.correctAnswer: They shall dwell safely, no longer prey to heathen or beasts
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 34:28-29 promises a future where God’s people will dwell safely without fear or hunger, reflecting the messianic peace in Isaiah 11:6-9 and Revelation 7:15-17.
